bibl.title: Layman's Case History, by John H. Andrus, March 1, 1938

div1.p: Andrus' medical history describes the development of the spinal condition that has left him bedridden.

div1.head: Layman's Case History, by John H. Andrus, March 1, 1938
div1.p:
Born Pennsylvania, October 7, 1879. Father died at 55 of Creep-
ing Paralysis. Mother is vigorous and in comparatively good
health at 80. A sister died at 24 and a brother at 36 of tuber-
culosis.

In 1889, when an army recruit learning to ride, the pounding of
a horse at a trot brought severe pain at base of spine and in ab-
domen. This punishment lasted approximately three months when I
was injured and, later, transferred to unmounted service.
Xrays have shown that I have one more vertebrae than normal.
It occurs to me that spine may have been injured at that time.

In 1901, during the early stages of an attack of yellow fever, pain
in back was very severe and back arching most pronounced.

In 1908 or 1909 fell and struck small of back on steps. Soreness
and lameness gradually diminished. Disappeared within few weeks.

About 1912 began having occasional severe pains in abdomen.
Attacks gradually became more frequent. Discovered that hot appli-
cations to BACK brought relief. About 1914 began having pains in
back - especially at night.

In 1918 X-ray showed arthritis of spine. Wore spinal brace - steel
band over hips and crutch supports under arm-pits - until bedfast.

On three occasions - always in the spring - condition became so
acute had to go to bed for about six weeks. Attacks responded to
strapping, rheumatic medication and rest.

From 1917 until bedfast was never a day without pain. Frequently
cold sleep only by use of hot water bottle or pad. A chill or
muscular exertion would mean added pain. Only able to continue
at work because of executive position.

About 1922 developed bronchial cough that would not respond to
treatment. Still have it but with greatly lessened severity.

About 1929 began to have occasional attacks of paroxysmal tacchy-
cardia. Attacks increased in frequency and were at worst during
time I was at Walter Reed Hospital. On one occasion there an
attack lasted 22 hours with a beat of 184. This condition is
now under control of one grain of digitalis daily.

In December, 1931, developed neuritis in upper arms, shoulders and
neck with aggravation of back pains. Gradually grew worse des-
pite medication and electrical treatments. Feet and hands grad-
ually numbed. Began to lose power to hold things in hands.
Stumbled in walking. Could not properly “steer” feet. Had to
be helped to and from work and careened from walls to furniture
in getting about.

March 1, 1932, went to bed for a “rest”. Am still “resting.”
Hands and legs gradually became paralyzed. Hands were in clutch-
ing position - could not be opened or closed. Numbness of hands,
forearms and feet more pronounced.
John H. Andrus.
Page 2.
Layman's case History.

May 13, 1932, went to Walter Reed Hospital. No control of bladder
or bowels. In efforts to ascertain cause, Wasserman, spinal taps,
tubercular and blood tests all negative. It was found that I had
a healed tubercular lesion of one lung. For a period of five weeks
there was gradual increase in use of hands and feet. Was placed
in wheel chair, in reclining position, and in three days was in much
worse condition than before.

Bone graft of spine was considered but discarded because of wide
involvement. Several vertebrae are fused together.

Oct. 6, 1932, returned home. Surgeons at Walter Reed Hospital
told me that they could not hope to make me better but only to keep
me from getting worse.

There has been a very gradual but marked improvement since that
time. Control of bladder, bowels, hands and feet was almost nor-
mal by the end of 1934. The sensatory nerves have never funct-
ioned as near normal as the motor nerves.

For about a year I have had neuritis in the neck and shoulders and
a constant headache. Condition is aggravated by elevating head of
bed, even momentarily.
